turn.text: But not in her specific private dealing with any private individual, it wouldn't be.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, I think I got the line straightened out anyway.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: I got into the question here of what barriers are placed in the path of these people who wanted this particular ordinance and I have read a stack of cases I guess this high and right now, I would say they're all piled on the floor of my mind and I couldn't sort anything up and tell which or any of them ought to be catalogued but I drafted a little statement here which I thought was in the sense the rule would apply here as to whether or not there had been unreasonable barriers placed in the way for these people to accomplish what they want and I think we go back basically to the proposition that this really is a political duel or a political competition.
Someone wanted fair housing and someone didn't want fair housing.

Now, as I see it, in a political duel between those who want a certain regulation and between those who oppose it if the state or the city in this particular case -- the city or the state in this particular case may not place in the way of those who desire it any barriers which without the state or here the city's total political system taken as a whole any barriers which are especially difficult of surmounting by comparison with those barriers that normally stand in the way are those who wish to use the political process to get what they want.
Now, in coming to the answer to --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Would you amend your -- would you amend your hypothesis there to this extent to say that this was a political combat between those who wanted to protect their constitutional rights and those who wanted to deny them to them and could you proceed from that and get the same result?

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Well, I would say that I'd have to grant that certainly those people have the right to their constitutional rights and it would have to fit in whatever process the city or the state involved, included, would have to be rights that are allowed and permitted under the Federal Constitution.
Of course, that would be basic in this assumption here.

Now, so I say that the fact about the way this particular charter amendment ended up was that it's easier for those who desire to get fair housing with it than it was before because I'm sure this Court can conceive and I certainly do of city council's right in our own, my own area who wouldn't pass fair housing.
So, therefore what are they going to have to do with those who want it?
They're going to have it get referred.
Those who would want to have it eliminated; they will have to use the process of referendum.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So, am I correct that we already have fair housing enacted?

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Yes.
No, we do not have it.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I said at this time, we already have it.

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Well, no because in the state court of Ohio says that we did not because it was suspended.
There was no fair housing law --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Up until it was suspended, you did have it and so you helped by taking it away.
That's where you lose me.

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Well, until that the ordinance become effective, Your Honor, it seems to me we wouldn't have it.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I would also assume that the ordinance that was passed would become effective.

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Well, again getting back to the total procedures which are permissible --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What more it was accomplished other than that under your argument that Akron save the money of the Commission?
What else did you say?

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Well, --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: In Akron.

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Well, because I think the state commission was far better equipped to handle the complaint, that's another thing.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is it in operation now?

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Yes, it's in operation now and real estate people are regulated by the state.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And would it handle this complaint?

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Oh, yes.
It's going to be my judgment that it would.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I'm going to let you interpret your own law but I would feel much better if I were an ordinary citizen if I had three protections than if I had two.

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Well, there are those who feel we have too many laws overlapping as they are and my own judgment is that since this is a total problem that we ought to regulate statewide that ought to be done that way because as I just said there are many of this municipalities in Akron who aren't going to have, do not have one and never will have one in my own humble judgment and so --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, is it your -- is it your opinion that the state law preempts this whole situation?

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Well, preempt -- the state is now in and I'm sure that if Akron tried to do anything that the state found offensive to the way it was handling then that would be held improper.

I think the cities could have -- the cities are allowed to have laws which are not in conflict with the general laws so if we had some -- if it didn't disturb what the states got it wouldn't -- there would be no problem.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I must say Mr. Vinopal, I have trouble seeing how we can accept your insistence that the state law indeed preempts whatever words you want to use, despises any state -- municipal regulation in this if your state courts haven't said so.
How can we proceed on this case on that premise?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It's not your position that the state law replaces this because as a matter of Ohio law, that doesn't happen.
Any city, any home rule city can have an ordinance so long as it's not with conflict with state law and then neither one of the other supersedes or preempts the other.
Each is a viable law, isn't that correct?

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Yes.
Of course, my position that since --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It's never your position that the relief asked for by the plaintiff in this case is now provided by state law.

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: That -- that's my position that there was a state law which provides the relief that she could had.
By the way, this was a mandamus case --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, if it is, I still don't see -- that enables this Court to escape the determination on the constitutional question that's been presented to her.
I gather that's the whole gist of your argument, is it?

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Well, it seems -- yes, that's the one face of it but if this party had other remedies, it seems to me would be a moot question and on that basis, it ought to be concerned with this Court.
And of course we have -- now have the federal law.
Well, anyway, to get back to Justice Marshall, why as I say anyone starting from scratch, if I may use that word, who would want fair housing would have to take a tour.
If they found an unfriendly council, they would have to take it to referendum.
Now, that is not necessary.
Under the procedure now, council may had any time to put this fair housing ordinance before the people and so therefore the barrier --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: These other communities are not before us.

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Am I correct?
The only community is Akron.

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And Akron had a fair housing ordinance and that's the case we are deciding.
Now, if you made it easier for Cleveland and all the other cities, that wouldn't affect Akron as I see it.

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: If I may just a moment here.
The Supreme Court of Ohio made this statement Your Honor on that subject at page 50 of the record.
It is obvious therefore that if Section 137 of the Akron charter is valid, its words require the conclusion that the ordinance relied upon by realtor had ceased to be effective.
Immediately, that ordinance was in effect when the charter section was adopted and the ordinance was never approved by the electors, has never been approved by the electors.
So that in the sense from the time, for the 25 days, --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But I read this in saying if Section 137 is valid.
If, and that's the point that's before this Court right now, is it valid or not?
Isn't that the issue?

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Yes, yes.
Well, of course we contend that it's valid because it sets up no particular extra, unusual burdens.
The classification in order to be obnoxious I think this Court has generally said must be arbitrary and having no reasonable basis.
Well, certainly if the people want to refer -- have referred to the question of fair housing would not seem to be unreasonable in view of the environment that existed at the time.
Now --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: In view of what?

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: In view of the environment that existed at the time, namely that there was pending going in the state, the activity of having a state law that possibly that the enforcement provisions of a city ordinance may not have been effective any way in view of those things, in view of the fact that it's not necessary to have one that this was the first opportunity in I would say that people could have to decide whether they wanted one or not since council had elected to pass the ordinance the way they did.
So in view of all of those things, I don't see that it's unreasonable at all that they should desire to do it this way.

So that really, all it has to be done now is to have council bring it to the voters, saving anyone who wanted to have fair housing, the obligation or the need for getting out a referendum petition, granting as justice says indicated it for the 25 days, there was a law but nothing had ever happened.
The Commission had never got organized.

There was -- everyone conceded I think at the time that they were waiting to see what was going on at the state courts with respect to overland, with respect to whether we're going to have state law or not.
So in view, I'll grant you that maybe one of the things but taking overall, the environment was favorable to those who wanted to do it this way in my humble judgment.
Oh!
Now as to other barriers of course council has spoken of the tax ordinance and that was one of their chief complaints that we had.
These people had heavier burdens.

Well, this ordinance was singled out while it wasn't as they have indicated here both these tax procedures and then also there's another one which is not in my brief and I regret in preparing for this case that I -- being my first trip over the road, I perhaps may note down what I should have namely with respect to where Mrs. Hunter now resides and with respect to another charter in Section 39 regarding franchisers says this that if anyone wants a franchise for public utility, every such proposed grant and every proposed renewal or extension of such grant by ordinance passed by the council shall be subject to referendum.
There, anyone who wants to have some sort of franchise stands the risk right off the back of having the people vote on the subject if they want to circulate petitions for that purpose.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Wouldn't you assume that utility is better shaped financially to get a referendum than a property owner?

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Well, some of them are but some of that I dealt with a little fellow with the bus line who I had to help get a franchise with the city, was put to bankrupt when he started.
But I'll say even he would be better off.
Yes, I'd agree.
Well --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Perhaps, it's arguable that this case will be more likely the public utility charter provision if the latter said that utility charters may be issued to white people without a referendum but if any utility charters can be issued to Negroes then you got to have a referendum.

Because as I understand your adversary's argument, he is pitching his case on that narrow point of racial -- alleged racial discriminations and as I understand this case, if for example, the provision adopted here had said that all legislation, all ordinances regulating terms, conditions, manner, etcetera of sale of real estate have to be submitted to the voters, then the same line of argument would not apply.
That's -- that's my understanding of his argument and that's why I put to you the alternative case with respect to utility franchise.

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Well, of course, granting this is the element of the racial discrimination but in the sense we look at on this instance was an ordinance dealing with a regulation of a subject and of course one of the subject was the sale of housing whether it was to Negroes, to whatever classification of people was.

It covered namely the subject of the sale and the rental of property and in that sense, I think that the people definitely had a right to consider that like they have done in other situations in their charter haven't referred to them for the purpose of whether they wanted it or not.
Not merely because they ought to go slow in this area but because of the other issues that I've mentioned, namely that it was still going through the state courts.

It was still being looked at into by the state legislator and also by virtue of the fact that really if we're going to regulate this thing and do this properly right possibly that it plays out to be done with the state because really in the area that we're dealing with here, it's subject involving real estate people, the way they handle this business and as I pointed out, that's the basic subject.
The few transactions between private people is a nullity anymore.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Why do you assume that we have to go slow in this area?

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: No, I -- my statement was that not necessarily.
I didn't say that.
I know that the Court said but that isn't -- I wouldn't necessarily make that --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I understood you to say just a moment ago that because it was necessary to go slow in this area.

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: No, I didn't speak loud enough.
I said regardless of that.
I made that an exception to my statement and I said my earlier --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Regardless of what?

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: My position is that the need to go slow isn't an element in here as to why the people would want to have this.
I don't consider that really vital to the thing.
I -- I think that the basic other interest, what I've talked about here.
Well, here we are.

Here's a big subject we're going to get into and by the way of course I can't go off the record but I understood that the real estate people were really the ones who were in favor of having the Act down the state in having it where it could be regulated.

And since we're getting into a vast subject of dealings with transactions involving the financing and sale, in the mortgaging interest and all of those things on property, well, I will conclude by saying that it seems to --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But Mr. Vinopal, could I ask you a question please?

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Didn't this ordinance do two things?
It said that a certain kind of ordinance can't be effective without the vote of the people.
That's one thing it is.

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Amendment, yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.
But then it also said that an ordinance -- a particular ordinance that's on the books is suspended.

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now, why can't the -- why can't a -- don't you think there's separate question involved here of whether a city may just drop and repeal an ordinance because this charter did at least did that may have gone farther and did something that's arguably impermissible?

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: But didn't it just gotten repeal among other things just suspend an existing ordinance.
Yes, it did that and --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, don't we have to hold that therefore that if the city may not -- for you to lose; don't we have to hold that a city may not repeal an ordinance?

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Yes, but I think a city can repeal an ordinance because there are the procedures and the machinery was adopted for their purpose.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What you're suggesting as an argument you might make?

turn.speaker: alvin_c_vinopal
turn.label: Mr. Alvin C. Vinopal
turn.text: Well, there are several arguments that I'll think about tonight perhaps that I ought to say.
But I'm going to close with this that not only several of your fistful.
That iceberg under what I presented here is pretty large and it was a good argument but I didn't make it.

It seems to me that we don't need a hatchet operation here, that after all, we do have decent, we have surgical machinery that is taking care of this problem by virtue of the state and the federal law and the 1869 Act and that therefore we ought to do something now which would amputate the whole governmental machinery, the process of initiative referendum which is really structured for the local communities and that's another argument I should have made.
This is after all, this is only local.
Maybe I did touch on that.
This isn't statewide.
This doesn't cover everybody.
This is just Akron and so my final word is that we shouldn't burn down the barn to roast the pig.
I think with that I shall close.
Thank you gentlemen.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Carter, you have a few moments left.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Carter, how do you answer Justice White's question?

turn.speaker: robert_l_carter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Carter
turn.text: Well, Mr. Justice White's question about the repeal?
I think that in terms of answering, it seems to me that Akron has done more than merely repealing the statute.
Now, what Akron does --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It has done that?

turn.speaker: robert_l_carter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Carter
turn.text: It has done that clause.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: There are two sentences that were put.
I gather your or am I wrong?
What your particular concern, would it that sentencing, any such ordinance in effect shall seek to be effective until approved by the electorate.

turn.speaker: robert_l_carter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Carter
turn.text: That's right but the point that it's --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, if that -- if you will prevail as to that sentence, is that the end of the case without reaching the first sentence?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Although as I understood your argument, you've been arguing about what's to the first sentence that you may not single out a housing discrimination ordinance as the kind must be submitted to the electorate and another.
That's been the import of your argument, I thought.

turn.speaker: robert_l_carter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Carter
turn.text: The -- I think it's a matter of fact that we -- what we have here are the two bases.
As you indicated, the ordinance did two things.
The amendment to the charter did two things.
It said, that fair housing ordinance that you have on the statute books is not cannot go into effect and is suspended pending a vote of the people.
It said -- it said secondly that no fair housing can passed or fair housing ordinance can be passed except by this process.
Now, it seems to me --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You did that in arguing -- up to now, you've just been arguing about the latter aspect of it.

turn.speaker: robert_l_carter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Carter
turn.text: Because the latter aspect of it in -- I have been arguing I think about both of them because I think that's the question that Mr. Justice Stewart asked.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you mean we don't --

turn.speaker: robert_l_carter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Carter
turn.text: Mr. Justice Stewart said to me I think that would I have to make an argument about this is the statute have not been on the books?
Couldn't I make the same argument here if this without any prior history of fair housing that this -- there's the first sentence that had fit in, and I said of course I would be.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Because it could have had quite the same lawsuit but you would have exactly the same constitutional argument.

turn.speaker: robert_l_carter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Carter
turn.text: Yes, I would have the same constitutional argument.
I think I would yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I agree with you and that's why I say that's what have been the burden of your argument is the singling out of this kind of an ordinance for special treatment.

But you still have to get by the -- you still have to say that in the process of putting on this kind of a, what you an arguably unconstitutional provision, that the state may not repeal an existing ordinance.
Do we have to decide the whole for you that a state may not repeal an existing ordinance?

turn.speaker: robert_l_carter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Carter
turn.text: You don't have to decide that a state may not repeal an existing ordinance.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I mean an existing fair housing ordinance?
Do we have to decide that?

turn.speaker: robert_l_carter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Carter
turn.text: I don't think you have to.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: robert_l_carter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Carter
turn.text: Because of the fact that that I think that what you have decide it seems to me --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Because that's one thing the state did here.

turn.speaker: robert_l_carter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Carter
turn.text: Well, that's one thing the state here but the state did more than that and what the state did more --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know but why do we even have to get to it the more?

turn.speaker: robert_l_carter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Carter
turn.text: Because of the fact that if the state having done more, it seems to me that in so far as my argument is concerned that it is a simpler constitutional question to indicate that the state cannot single out these people and bar any legislation to some.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Let me ask you this Mr. Carter.
Suppose the Court decided that the first sentence of this ordinance was unconstitutional --

turn.speaker: robert_l_carter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Carter
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- and stopped it or it said the first sentence is unconstitutional but it was perfectly constitutional for the state to repeal this ordinance so there is no ordinance in effect in Akron but the provision singling out fair housing ordinances as those which must go to a referendum or an initiative is unconstitutional, would that satisfy you or not?

turn.speaker: robert_l_carter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Carter
turn.text: Well, it would appear to me that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: In short what is this case about, is it?

turn.speaker: robert_l_carter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Carter
turn.text: This case is about the fact that the ordinance of this kind, the state has singled out a particular class of legislation and said that you may not act this without going through certain processes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, let's assume the Court agreed with you on that.

turn.speaker: robert_l_carter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Carter
turn.text: That the state has also said -- the state has done more Mr. Justice White and say that it has repealed the ordinance because it says --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you want us to say that the repeal is also unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: robert_l_carter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Carter
turn.text: I want you to say that repeal is unconstitutional with the burdens that have been placed upon it at the present time.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, we can say the burdens are unconstitutional but why does that make the repeal unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: robert_l_carter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Carter
turn.text: Well, if you say that the burdens are unconstitutional, it seems to me that the issue as to whether a simple repeal is unconstitutional is not my case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, then you want us to reach whether or not the ordinance is now in existence in Akron.

turn.speaker: robert_l_carter
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Carter
turn.text: That's right.

And as far as we're concerned Your Honor, our view is that we are here -- this ordinance ought to be struck down for the reasons that have been indicated that it's a violation of Equal Protection Clause.
